families.name: Umayyad (Dinasty)
history: The dynasty began with Abd Shams ibn Abd Manaf al-Qurash (Medieval Lands, 2019, West Asia & North Africa (1)) that has his descendants described in Chronicon Albeldense (Strabo, Walahfrid, 1879, pp. 577 ; Medieval Lands, 2019, West Asia & North Africa (1)).

people.name: Artiqa
history: During the second half of the 13th century the named "Livro Velho de Linhagens" was written (Mattoso, José, 1982, pp. 45), but the original work did not reach our time (Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 135), this means that people wrote the history more than 300 years after her birthday. The temporal distance is not the unique issue with 'Livro Velho de Linhagens', it is also necessary to consider that both "Codex de Roda" (Lacarra, José M., 1945) and "Crônica de Sampiro" (Santos, Francisco C., 1921) written in the same century that supposed events happened did not have one word about her. These issues converted the original text for what is known today as "Lenda da Gaia", because Gaia was the place where events happened (Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 180-181; Rei, António, 2013, pp. 21-36).

The count Don Pedro wrote his nobiliarchy few decades after "Livro Velho de Linhagens" adding details (Sousa, Manuel e F, et all (1696), pp. 4, 112-116) and when Gaio wrote the chapter about Maia's family, he only accepted what Don Pedro proposed (Felgueiras, Gaio, 1939, Tomo 18, pp. 11).

New research has been made to investigate what is proposed by 'Livro Velho de Linhagens' and followed for other nobiliarchy: António Rei suggests that her real name was 'Arîqa' (Rei, António, 2013, pp. 11-12), and she really marriae Ramiro II, while Francisco Doria years before published a paper, and shared in geneall (Geneall, 2001), where he follows the logic that she is descendant of Prohpet Muhammad, but with different ancestors. He also suggests that she married with Lovesendo Ramires, the hypothetical son of Ramiro II.

marriages.name: Ramiro II
history: There is no document nor chronicle that can confirm this person, today we only have citations either in genealogical books or in genealogical papers (Herculano, Alexandre, Scriptores, 1860, pp. 180-181; Rei, António, 2013, pp. 21-36).

marriages.name: Lovesendo Ramires
history: There is no document nor chronicle that can confirm this marriage (Geneall, 2001) or the person. This is a contradictory hypothesis with the previous one, because this person is a son at the previous.

It is possible to arrive in the conclusion we should have this person, because his hypothetical son was named Aboazar Lovesendes and this person would have as his first son a person named Lovesendo (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 208).
